awd_titl_txt: Character Varieties and Locally Homogeneous Geometric Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Studying all of the possible shapes of a geometric or mechanical object is a fundamental part of many problems in science and engineering, from understanding the folding of proteins or the formation of galaxies to programming autonomous vehicles to navigate complex terrain.  This research project will broaden our understanding of a class of such "shape space" problems in which the geometric objects are surfaces (i.e. flat or curved two-dimensional shapes) or closely related spaces built from higher-dimensional pieces assembled in a two-dimensional pattern. These are natural examples to study because of the frequent appearance of surface geometry in a wide variety of mathematical problems and applications.  In addition to contributing to mathematical knowledge, the computational and visualization components of this project will produce striking images of mathematical objects that exhibit their intricate structure and complexity in a way that can be appreciated by scientists and non-scientists alike.

A locally homogeneous geometric structure on a compact manifold determines a holonomy representation, which is a homomorphism from the fundamental group of the manifold into a Lie group.  The resulting map from the space of geometric structures to the space of group representations is always a local homeomorphism, but apart from a few classical examples (such as constant curvature geometries), the global behavior of the holonomy correspondence is not well understood.  The investigator will contribute to our understanding of this basic problem by studying cases in which analytic methods can be brought to bear.  For example, families of Anosov representations of surface groups in complex Lie groups are amenable to study through Kodaira-Spencer deformation theory, and through the application of tools from complex-analytic Teichmueller theory.  In other cases, such as real projective structures on compact surfaces and generalizations thereof, geometric structures can be understood in terms of the solutions of a system of partial differential equations on the underlying manifold, allowing geometric questions to be attacked through techniques such as asymptotic analysis, barriers, and maximum principles.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to better understand aspects of geometry that combine elements of two-dimensional objects (surfaces) with higher-dimensional objects.  The project made major progress on a number of fronts.  First, the main research program produced significant advances that appeared in journal publications and which were presented in lectures.  In most instances, these theoretical advances were guided by computer study and visualization, which is both a powerful tool for mathematical exploration and an excellent way to give college students and early-career graduate students a role in ongoing research that requires limited mathematical training.

Second, under the support of this award, the PI also pursued a number of activities to share mathematical work with a broader audience, including:

  • Organizing a yearly undergraduate mathematics symposium at the University of Illinois at Chicago
  • Co-organizing a Fall 2019 semester program "Illustrating Mathematics" at the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics at Brown University
  • Creating online tools for visualizing well-studied mathematical objects in new ways that exhibit their intricate structure in ways non-mathematicians can appreciate (e.g. http://www.dumas.io/slview/)

The PI's computation work under this project was guided by open source principles, and involved sharing data, code, and research results in a form that can be easily used by other researchers.  One of the projects (a collaboration with Andrew Neitzke) involved an extensive database of experimental results being archived in the Harvard Dataverse, and several projects produced new open-source software shared in online repositories.

Under this award, the PI also continued to organize and supervise undergraduate research projects, which provide college math majors with an important bridge from their traditional content-based coursework into the more open-ended world of research problems and literature exploration.  By preparing undergraduate students at UIC for graduate study in mathematics, such efforts aim to broaden participation in mathematical research and to help make the community's demographics more representative of the US population.
